questiontext.text:
Exercise

Using cylindrical polar coordinates with \(z=0\), verify Stokes' theorem for the vector field \(\underline{F} = \rho \underline{\hat{\rho}}+ \rho \cos \left(\displaystyle\frac{\pi \rho}{2}\right) \underline{\hat{\phi}}\) and the semi-circle \(\rho \le 1\), \(-\dfrac{\pi}{2} \le \phi \le \dfrac{\pi}{2}\).

  1. First find the \(z\)- component of the curl, \(({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \hat{z},\) and then select the correct answer from the options below.

    [Hint: remember the formula for the curl of a vector field in polar coordinates, and how to find the component in one direction.]

    1. \(({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \hat{z} = 2 \rho \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho\right) - \dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho^2 \sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho \right) \)

    2. \(({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \hat{z} = 2 \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho\right) - \dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho \sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho\right) \)

    3. \(({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \hat{z} = 2 \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho\right)\)

    \(({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \hat{z} = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

  2. Now evaluate the double integral \(\displaystyle \int \int_S ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} = \int \int_S ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \hat{z} \, \mathrm{d}A\), remembering the transformation of \(\mathrm{d}A\) into cylindrical polar coordinates.

    \(\displaystyle \int \int_S ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \hat{z} \, \mathrm{d}A =\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

  3. Now find the integral \(\displaystyle\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) by splitting the boundary \(C\) into 3 parts:

    1. First find \(\underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r},\) and then select the correct answer from the options below.

      [Hint: you may find it useful that \(\underline{\mathrm{d}r} = \hat{\underline{\rho}}\, \mathrm{d}\rho + \hat{\underline{\phi}}\, (\rho\, \mathrm{d}\phi)\)]

      1. \(\underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r} = \displaystyle \rho \, \mathrm{d}\rho + \rho^3 \cos(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho)\, \mathrm{d}\phi\)

      2. \(\underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r} = \displaystyle \rho \, \mathrm{d}\rho + \rho \cos(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho)\, \mathrm{d}\phi\)

      3. \(\underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r} = \displaystyle \rho \, \mathrm{d}\rho + \rho^2 \cos(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho) \, \mathrm{d}\phi\)

      \(\underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r} = \) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt3]]

    2. The contribution to \(\displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) along the radial segment \(\phi = -\dfrac{\pi}{2}\) is [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]] [[feedback:prt4]]

      [Note: think about the semi-circle, which part of the boundary is represented by \(\phi = -\dfrac{\pi}{2}\)?]

    3. The contribution to \(\displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) along the arc \(\rho = 1\) is [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]] [[feedback:prt5]]

      [Note: think about the semi-circle, which part of the boundary is represented by \(\rho = 1\)?]

    4. The contribution to \(\displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) along the radial segment \(\phi = \dfrac{\pi}{2}\) is [[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]] [[feedback:prt6]]

      [Note: think about the semi-circle, which part of the boundary is represented by \(\phi = \dfrac{\pi}{2}\)?]

  4. Hence find the total line integral \(\displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\)

    \(\displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r} = \) [[input:ans7]] [[validation:ans7]] [[feedback:prt7]]

generalfeedback.text:
We are asked to verify Stokes' theorem for the vector field \(\underline{F} = \rho \underline{\hat{\rho}}+ \rho \cos \left(\displaystyle\frac{\pi \rho}{2}\right) \underline{\hat{\phi}}\) and the semi-circle \(\rho \le 1\), \(-\dfrac{\pi}{2} \le \phi \le \dfrac{\pi}{2},\) using cylindrical polar coordinates with \(z=0\).

  1. We are asked to first find the \(z-\) component of the curl, \(({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \hat{z}.\)

    We know that in cylindrical coordinates we have

    curl \(\displaystyle \underline{F} = {\underline \nabla} \times \displaystyle \underline{F} = \frac{1}{\rho} \left|\begin{array}{ccc} \underline{\hat{\rho}} & \rho \underline{\hat{\phi}} & \underline{\hat{z}} \\ \\ \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ \\ F_{\rho} & \rho F_{\phi} & F_z \end{array} \right|\).

    Expanding the determinant to find the \(z\)- component, we get

    \(\qquad ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \hat{z} = \dfrac{1}{\rho}\left(\dfrac{\partial}{\partial \rho}\!\big(\rho F_{\phi}\big) \;-\; \dfrac{\partial F_{\rho}}{\partial \phi}\right)\)

    So here, with \(F_{\rho}=\rho, \, F_{\phi} = \rho \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho \right), \, F_z=0,\) the \(z\)- component of the curl becomes

    \(\begin{align} \qquad ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \hat{z} &= \dfrac{1}{\rho}\dfrac{\partial}{\partial \rho}\!\left(\rho \rho \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho\right)\right) \;-\; \dfrac{1}{\rho}\dfrac{\partial \rho}{\partial \phi} \\ &= \dfrac{1}{\rho} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial \rho} \left(\rho^2 \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho \right)\right), \quad \text{since} \, \rho \, \text{is independent of} \, \phi \\ &= 2 \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho\right) - \dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho \sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho\right), \quad \text{by using the product rule.} \end{align}\)

  2. We are now asked to evaluate the double integral \(\displaystyle \int \int_S ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} = \int \int_S ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \hat{z} \, \mathrm{d}A\), remembering the transformation of \(\mathrm{d}A\) into cylindrical polar coordinates. We know that \(\mathrm{d}A\) becomes \(\rho \, \mathrm{d}\rho \, \mathrm{d}\phi,\) and so we have

    \(\begin{align} \qquad \displaystyle \int \int_S ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} &= \int \int_S ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \hat{z} \, \mathrm{d}A \\ &= \int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \int_0^1 \left(2 \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho\right) - \dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho \sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho\right)\right) \rho \, \mathrm{d}\rho \, \mathrm{d}\phi \\ &= \int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \int_0^1 \left(2 \rho \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho\right) - \dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho^2 \sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho\right)\right) \, \mathrm{d}\rho \, \mathrm{d}\phi \\ &= \int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \left[\rho^2 \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho\right)\right]_0^1 \, \mathrm{d}\phi \\ &= \int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \right) \, \mathrm{d}\phi \\ &= \left[\phi \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \right) \right]_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \\ &= \pi \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \right) \\ &= 0. \end{align}\)

  3. We are now asked to find the integral \(\displaystyle\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) by splitting the boundary \(C\) into 3 parts:

    1. We are first asked to find \(\underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\)

      We know that \(\underline{\mathrm{d}r} = \hat{\underline{\rho}}\, \mathrm{d}\rho + \hat{\underline{\phi}}\, (\rho\, \mathrm{d}\phi)\), and \(\underline{F} = \rho \underline{\hat{\rho}}+ \rho \cos \left(\displaystyle\frac{\pi \rho}{2}\right) \underline{\hat{\phi}}\), so

      \(\qquad \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r} = \rho \, \mathrm{d}\rho + \rho^2 \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho \right) \mathrm{d}\phi.\)

    2. We are now asked to find the contribution to \(\displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) along the radial segment \(\phi = -\dfrac{\pi}{2}\)

      Along the radial segment \(\phi = -\dfrac{\pi}{2} \implies \mathrm{d}\phi = 0\), and with \(\rho: 0 \to 1\), the contribution becomes

      \(\qquad \displaystyle \int_0^1 \rho \mathrm{d}\rho = \left[\dfrac{\rho^2}{2}\right]_0^1 = \dfrac{1}{2}. \)

    3. We are now asked to find the contribution to \(\displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) along the arc \(\rho = 1\)

      Along the arc \(\rho = 1 \implies \mathrm{d}\rho = 0\), and with \(\phi: -\dfrac{\pi}{2} \to \dfrac{\pi}{2}\), the contribution becomes

      \(\qquad \displaystyle \int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \rho^2 \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \rho \right) \mathrm{d}\phi = \int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} \right) \mathrm{d}\phi = \pi \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right) = 0. \)

    4. We are now asked to find the contribution to \(\displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) along the radial segment \(\phi = \dfrac{\pi}{2}\)

      Along the radial segment \(\phi = \dfrac{\pi}{2} \implies \mathrm{d}\phi = 0\), and with \(\rho: 1 \to 0\), the contribution becomes

      \(\qquad \displaystyle \int_1^0 \rho \mathrm{d}\rho = \left[\dfrac{\rho^2}{2}\right]_1^0 = -\dfrac{1}{2}. \)

  4. We are asked to hence find the total line integral \(\displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\)

    The total line integral is equal to the sum of each of the 3 contributions along the boundary of the semi-circle, so

    \(\qquad \displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r} = \dfrac{1}{2} + 0 -\dfrac{1}{2} = 0\)

    This is the same as our calculated surface integral in part (b), as Stokes' theorem tells us.

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

qtest.description: Test case assuming the teacher's input gets full marks.
